ùó™ùóµùó∂ùó∞ùóµ ùòÑùóºùòÇùóπùó± ùòÜùóºùòÇ ùó∞ùóµùóºùóºùòÄùó≤: ùóî ùó¥ùòÇùóÆùóøùóÆùóªùòÅùó≤ùó≤ùó± $ùü±ùü¨ ùóºùóø ùóÆ ùü±ùü¨% ùó∞ùóµùóÆùóªùó∞ùó≤ ùòÅùóº ùòÑùó∂ùóª $ùü≠ùü¨ùü¨?

Most people take the sure $50‚Äîeven though the gamble has the same expected value.

Why? ùóïùó≤ùó∞ùóÆùòÇùòÄùó≤ ùòÑùó≤ ùó≥ùó≤ùóÆùóø ùóπùóºùòÄùòÄùó≤ùòÄ ùó∫ùóºùóøùó≤ ùòÅùóµùóÆùóª ùòÑùó≤ ùòÉùóÆùóπùòÇùó≤ ùó≤ùóæùòÇùó∂ùòÉùóÆùóπùó≤ùóªùòÅ ùó¥ùóÆùó∂ùóªùòÄ‚Äîthat‚Äôs loss aversion in action.

How a decision is framed shapes how we perceive risk, reward, and urgency.

In a famous study by Tversky & Kahneman (1981), participants were given two options for treating a deadly disease:

 Gain Frame: ‚ÄúThis treatment will save 200 out of 600 lives."
 Loss Frame: ‚ÄúThis treatment will result in 400 deaths out of 600."

Even though both statements describe the same outcome, far more people chose the "save 200 lives" option.

ùó™ùóµùòÜ?
 We fear losses more than we desire gains.
 Losing feels twice as painful as an equivalent gain feels rewarding.
 The way information is framed shifts our perception of risk.

ùóõùóºùòÑ ùòÅùóº ùó®ùòÄùó≤ ùóôùóøùóÆùó∫ùó∂ùóªùó¥ ùòÅùóº ùó†ùóÆùó∏ùó≤ ùóïùó≤ùòÅùòÅùó≤ùóø ùóóùó≤ùó∞ùó∂ùòÄùó∂ùóºùóªùòÄ:
 ùóòùó∫ùóΩùóµùóÆùòÄùó∂ùòáùó≤ ùòÑùóµùóÆùòÅ‚ÄôùòÄ ùóÆùòÅ ùòÄùòÅùóÆùó∏ùó≤: Instead of saying, ‚ÄúSign up for benefits,‚Äù highlight the loss: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt miss out on your exclusive benefits.‚Äù
 ùóßùòÇùóøùóª ùó∞ùóºùòÄùòÅùòÄ ùó∂ùóªùòÅùóº ùó∂ùóªùòÉùó≤ùòÄùòÅùó∫ùó≤ùóªùòÅùòÄ: Rather than ‚ÄúThis course costs $500,‚Äù say ‚ÄúInvest $500 to boost your career and increase your earning potential.‚Äù

When you are making a decision, ask yourself: ùóîùó∫ ùóú ùóøùó≤ùóÆùó∞ùòÅùó∂ùóªùó¥ ùòÅùóº ùòÅùóµùó≤ ùó∞ùóµùóºùó∂ùó∞ùó≤‚Äîoùóø ùòÅùóº ùóµùóºùòÑ ùó∂ùòÅ ùó∂ùòÄ ùó≥ùóøùóÆùó∫ùó≤ùó±?

Challenge Your Comfort Zone This Week!

As athletes, we often find ourselves pushing physical limits, but what about our mental and emotional boundaries? This week, I challenge you to step outside your comfort zone.

**What‚Äôs one thing you can commit to that makes you feel a little uncomfortable?**

It could be striking up a conversation with a teammate you‚Äôve never spoken to, trying a new training technique, or even sharing your personal goals with a mentor. Each small step can lead to significant growth both on and off the field.

Remember, growth happens when we embrace discomfort. By challenging ourselves, we not only enhance our skills but also develop resilience and confidence ‚Äì essential traits for success in athletics and life!

I‚Äôd love to hear what you decide to tackle this week. Share your challenges below, and let‚Äôs support each other in our journeys!

The easiest way for a boss to hide their incompetence? Blame you.

When you succeed -
It is because of their great management skills.

When you struggle -
it's because you are not good enough.

Most don‚Äôt even realise their own lack of skill is the real problem.

They never ask, ‚ÄúDid I fail as a leader?‚Äù
They assume ‚ÄúYou just weren‚Äôt good enough.‚Äù

And they slap a label on you: lazy, slow, disorganised, incompetent.

Sound familiar? Here‚Äôs how to know if your boss is setting you up to fail:

1Ô∏è‚É£ No Clear Expectations:
Your role feels like a moving target.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Lack of Resources:
You‚Äôre expected to win with no resources.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Constant Micromanagement:
Every move and decision is second-guessed.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Excessive Criticism:
Mistakes are magnified. Wins are ignored.

5Ô∏è‚É£ Isolation:
You‚Äôre left out of key meetings and conversations.

6Ô∏è‚É£ Changing the Rules:
The goalpost keeps moving.

7Ô∏è‚É£ Your Confidence is Crushed:
You start doubting yourself.

Checked off 3 or more? It‚Äôs not just you.

With the right leadership, the UK could compete with the US in so many ways‚Ä¶ but a lot needs to change: 

Including our attitude towards success, entrepreneurship and failure.

comments.commentText: I completely agree with your perspective on the UK's potential to compete with the US Steven Bartlett. However, I believe that in addition to changing our attitude towards success, entrepreneurship and failure, we also need to focus on fostering a culture of innovation and creativity. This means investing in education and research, encouraging collaboration between businesses and universities, and providing support for startups and small businesses. Furthermore, we need to prioritize diversity and inclusion in our workforce, as diverse teams have been shown to be more innovative and successful. By embracing these changes, I believe that the UK can truly become a global leader in innovation and entrepreneurship.

The UK possesses extraordinary potential to compete with the US on the global stage, yet it is clear that we need a transformative shift in our mindset and approach. This shift transcends mere policy adjustments and demands a cultural renaissance.

We must create an environment that embraces innovation, wholeheartedly celebrates the entrepreneurial spirit, and reframes setbacks as invaluable learning experiences rather than failures. Moreover, we must urgently tackle our energy dependency. The soaring costs are not just a temporary setback; they significantly drag on our economy, affecting households and businesses alike.

To unlock our true potential, we need bold, visionary leadership that confronts these challenges head-on and galvanises a new era of ambition and resilience. What critical changes do you believe are necessary for the UK to truly thrive? Let‚Äôs engage in this vital discussion!

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely! Cultivating a growth mindset and embracing risk are crucial for fostering innovation and driving competitiveness. Let‚Äôs champion change!

postsData.content:
The biggest wealth transfer in history is happening right now:

The next wave of millionaires won't come from startups...

They'll come from old businesses that embrace this ONE thing.

Here's the SMB strategy that will dominate the next decade:

$72.6 trillion will move between generations by 2046.

The startup game is getting harder - 90% fail within 5 years.

But there's a massive opportunity hiding in plain sight:

32.5M small businesses in the US alone are ready for transformation.

I call it SMB 2.0:

The fusion of old economy infrastructure with new economy technology.

Think about Tesla - it's not a car company, it's a software company that happens to make cars.

The data is crystal clear.

Digitally mature companies are:

‚Ä¢ 50% more likely to grow revenue
‚Ä¢ 8x more likely to create jobs
‚Ä¢ 14x more likely to innovate
‚Ä¢ 3x more likely to export

But most of these businesses are held back by legacy systems, costing them 15% in revenue annually.

Let me show you a real example:

Ace Hardware's digital transformation resulted in:

‚Ä¢ 3.5x increase in online sales
‚Ä¢ 28% higher transaction sizes
‚Ä¢ 15% reduction in inventory costs
‚Ä¢ 98% higher customer satisfaction

Manufacturing companies implementing AI and IoT are seeing:

‚Ä¢ 80% reduction in prototyping time
‚Ä¢ 50% reduction in time-to-market
‚Ä¢ 20% reduction in downtime
‚Ä¢ 30% reduction in costs

By 2025, 75% of business leaders will be leveraging digital platforms to adapt to new markets.

After facilitating over $200M in acquisitions, I've learned the key to capitalizing on this wealth transfer isn't just technology.

You need three things:

‚Ä¢ Access to the right deals
‚Ä¢ A proven framework for evaluating opportunities
‚Ä¢ A clear roadmap for post-acquisition transformation

The entrepreneurs who succeed aren't the most tech-savvy.

They're the ones who understand how to identify undervalued businesses and deliver real improvements.

Buy then build.

-

3 years ago this week, I quit my day job to go all in on Bloom.

It wasn't at all.

It was one of the easiest decisions I've ever made.

I felt peace, confidence, and total excitement.

It had been my dream to build something mission-driven since I was a teenager.

I remember telling my parents, "I want to do something with my life that helps people abroad, but I don't know what."

And in the early, validation days of, we saw our first team members overseas more than double their income.

Plus, our first clients told us our staff were just as good as US talent and they already wanted to hire more from us.

I knew we were onto something special. A once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.

And I had a partner inwho was just as all-in as I was.

So it was easy to make the leap.

Now 2025 marks our FOURTH year of business! 

We're arguably the fastest-growing bootstrapped business in the state of Utah.

Impacting thousands of people around the globe who have joined our staff.

And revolutionizing how work is done for our clients ‚Äî household-name companies that people use every day.

I'm nostalgic this week thinking back to making the plunge 3 years ago, but I'm even more excited for the next 3 years ahead.

We're just at the beginning of our story.

More to come!

postsData.content:
Our kids don't want our life.

Who could blame them?

This is what success looks like for a lot of people today:

- a fancy title
- asking for permission
- never seeing your kids
- never being present with people you love
- asking for growth and waiting to be promoted
- counting down the days until vacation each year
- waiting for a boss to give you 2% salary increase
- coming back from vacation thinking: "now it‚Äôs going to be different, I won‚Äôt let work rule my life‚Äù. 2 days goes by: you‚Äôre in the same sh!t
- so tired from sitting in back to back meetings all day that you‚Äôve started to forget who you are and started dying from the inside

‚Üí This is just being hi-jacked 24/7.

We seriously need to REDEFINE what success looks like.

It should be:

- owning our time
- not be held back
- setting our own rules
- design the life we want
- decide our own income
- ownership and accountability
- having time to experience life
- working from wherever we want
- time with family and being present
- waking up every day feeling challenged, curious, excited, hungry and at the same time content with life

The traditional 9-to-5 is just a hamster wheel.

It's a broken old model that hasn‚Äôt been updated in a very long time.

It leaves you zero autonomy.

‚Üí It does its job though: it keeps you busy and focused on just getting through the day.

It leaves you no time to do anything else than building someone else's dream.

We have to do better than this.

Do you agree?

postsData.content:
The gregariousness of the human species, the formation of clans and tribes, groups and societies, sects and religions, nations and States, all tend to one fundamental end, the finding of oneness in this world of infinite variation, the unity that eludes but which is in the heart of things, secret, yet, sending ever the message that it lies in wait to be discovered, the profound end of evolution, the transcendence of phenomenal life, the infinitude of existence. Man hears this voice of freedom coming from within but mistakes its source as a revelation from without from an omnipotent arbiter inhabiting a higher heaven with a rod to strike the errant one who chooses not to fall in line with the dictum from above. Fear and ignorance and their foster-child arrogance have thus gripped the world for ages, superstition bred in the primitive mind devoid of enlightenment of reason or real inspiration have plunged the world with bloodshed such that we feel the echoes of those ancient clashes even today with technological tentacles holding us in their death-grip like never before. But there is hope as well. Scientific knowledge and the Vedanta are releasing humanity from the insensate culture of its brutal past and the combination of the two will bring forth a renaissance of all that has been highest and noblest in human history with added discoveries of the future ushering in a golden age for all of humankind. There will be resistance, often violent ones, to thwart the progress of man for the conservative element in the organic system is hard to rid of, but victory shall be sealed with fresher generations seeing the light of day and accepting what is true and best in human culture as the future man scales higher peaks en route to the summit of realizations that we are outwardly many, inwardly one. An enforced homogeneity will not work for it is against the basic principle of Nature, the variegation of life built on the foundation of the essential oneness of existence. Unity in diversity will have to be accepted as the one basis for a variegated flowering of the human species. Only on such an enlightened acceptance of each other may we be sure of the promotion of peace and harmony of the peoples of the world, only on such a universal understanding of truth may we be able to truly love our fellow-beings as we move towards a world civilization with a common agenda, the freedom of all, fellowship with all and the well-being of all that inhabit this beautiful home of ours, Planet earth.
Written by Sugata Bose

postsData.content:
BIOMIMICRY CONTINUUM ‚Äì Part 5 ‚Äì CURATING Agentic Expertise
Multidisciplinary expertise is critical to correctly define the key premises driving problem analysis and solution architecture, and the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem (left image) enables capturing that expertise as a reusable computing asset.

The current AI chaos is due to 70 years of narrow and unexamined premises. The promise of AGI in the 1950s was rooted in premises that have been disproven by real-world evidence but blindly adhered to by those making today‚Äôs AGI claims. Key examples:

-Premise: language is the source of intelligence
-Reality: intelligence is the source of language - babies are intelligent before they can speak

-Premise: data is a representation of the real world
-Reality: data is the output of a machine and represents only what the machine was designed to capture

-Premise: the brain constructs objects by identifying frequent patterns of object bits
-Reality: the brain contains networks of abstract concept cells which fire when the concepts are presented in diverse versions and formats (text, image, sound, etc.)

-Premise: neural networks imitate how the brain reasons by processing massive data exhaustively
-Reality: the brain computes the relevance of inputs using inhibition networks, filtering out over 99.99% of sensory data

There are more, but the point is that the main objectives of curation are:
1-Ensure that knowledge from all relevant domains is included in the ontology
2-Map the relevant knowledge concepts across the domains to problem and solution concepts
3-Maintain the landscape concepts (science, business, regulation, etc.) reasonably updated

To enable these objectives, the custodian systems must support:
1-Biomimetic digital twinning of problem and solution concepts
2-Independent update by authorized experts
2-Simulation and testing of the impact of proposed updates across the ontology architecture

The methodology and technology to build this type of biomimetic digital twin ecosystem exist, we have produced published results, and I have discussed this in my posts.

The vision of the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem in the image, however, is in early stages and will require committed partners with the necessary resources who want to participate in shaping the implementation of this new paradigm.
postsData.commentAdded: Exciting insights! Challenging outdated premises is crucial for AIs evolution. Looking forward to seeing how the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem progresses!

For the players that also have distinctive social followings, it‚Äôs a unique recognition that this person has a unique voice that‚Äôs already earning appeal as a brand onto itself, and that match will certainly elevate their brand beyond simple athletic performance.

The Power of Leadership in Business 
Great businesses aren‚Äôt just built on ideas; they‚Äôre built on strong leadership.  As a Founder & CEO, I‚Äôve learned that leadership is more than just giving orders‚Äîit‚Äôs about inspiring, guiding, and empowering your team.
Here‚Äôs what I believe makes a great leader:
 Vision & Clarity ‚Äì A leader must set a clear direction and keep the team aligned.
 Leading by Example ‚Äì Actions speak louder than words. If you want dedication, show it first.
 Empowering Others ‚Äì Trust your team, delegate responsibilities, and help them grow.
 Adaptability ‚Äì The best leaders embrace change and adjust to challenges with confidence.

postsData.content:
I GOT LAID OFF‚Ä¶ and it was the best thing that ever happened to me

I remember sitting at my desk, the ping of the email hitting my inbox

Subject: Organizational Restructuring.

I didn‚Äôt even need to open it to know what was coming. That sinking feeling hit me like a freight train‚ÄîI was laid off. For a moment, the world seemed to stop.

What now? Mortgage payments, bills ‚Äîhow was I going to keep it all together?


It‚Äôs natural to feel defeated, overwhelmed, maybe even a little lost. First, change your state. Move your body, get outside, breathe deeply.

When I felt crushed, I didn‚Äôt stay in bed. I put on my running shoes and hit the pavement, joined a dance class, picked up cooking, socialized.

Motion creates emotion. When you shift your physiology, your mind follows.


When you‚Äôre laid off, it‚Äôs tempting to retreat into a shell, but that‚Äôs the exact opposite of what you need.

Don‚Äôt just send a bland, ‚ÄúHey, I‚Äôm looking for work‚Äù message. Instead, let your network see your passion and skills. Post about what you‚Äôve achieved, share what you‚Äôre excited about, and make it personal.

When I reached out to my network, I didn‚Äôt just ask for help‚ÄîI showed them how I could add value. And the opportunities started rolling in.


A layoff might feel like a door closing, but what if it‚Äôs the universe forcing you to knock on the one that leads to your dream job?

I'd say ‚ÄúLife is happening for you, not to you.‚Äù


While you‚Äôre job hunting, carve out time to pursue the dream.

Always wanted to shift industries? Now‚Äôs the time.
Been eyeing that certification or side hustle? Dive in.

When I was laid off, I didn‚Äôt just settle for any job‚ÄîI aimed higher. And guess what? I landed a role that paid more and aligned perfectly with my passions.


You are stronger than this moment. You are bigger than your job title. This layoff? It‚Äôs just a plot twist in your success story.

So feel the hit, eat that ice cream, but then GET UP. Rally your network, chase that dream, and show the world that a setback isn‚Äôt the end‚Äîit‚Äôs the fire that forges your next big win.

Because you, my friend, are unstoppable.

comments.commentText: This is the kind of perspective that turns setbacks into stepping stones. More people need to hear this Kiran Babu

postsData.content:
AI isn't a magic wand for design... But when designers master the when and how of using AI in their workflow - the result can be amazing.


Last year, inspired by design educators likeand, and together with my colleague Shir Atar , I took on a challenge with my Industrial Design students at HIT: exploring how AI could fit into the design process.

The idea was simple but ambitious‚Äîlearning by doing.The students developed their own methods for using AI tools, combining them with traditional techniques and personal insights. They didn‚Äôt stop there‚Äîthey turned their discoveries into tutorial videos to share with the wider design community. Fast forward to today: we‚Äôre in the second year of this journey, and the results continue to inspire me.
This year, nine more student groups tackled diverse applications of AI in design, from AI-driven Ideation and AI-VR integration to re imagining mock-ups and 3D modeling workflows.
The outcome? A collection of tutorials showing how AI can elevate the design process, now available for anyone curious about integrating AI into their work.
A few lessons stand out from this experience:
Letting go of the fear of change makes experimenting with AI feel less intimidating‚Äîit‚Äôs just another powerful tool in our creative toolbox.
Starting small, like testing AI on one part of the design process, can spark new methods that inspire and elevate creativity.
The magic lies in personalization‚Äîfinding the unique mix of tools that works for you.
It‚Äôs been a great experience to guide students as they explore how designers can shape the future with AI, rather than letting it shape us.
*Both the website and videos are in Hebrew, but (AI) subtitles are available we are working on a translated version to be up and running soon.

Amir Tabch

postsData.content:
Great leaders take it in stride‚Äîeven when it‚Äôs a brick to the face

Leadership is a lot like walking through a crowded street: no matter how smoothly you navigate, someone‚Äôs going to bump into you, step on your foot, or spill their coffee down your shirt. & if you‚Äôre leading anything worthwhile, you‚Äôre going to get hit with far worse‚Äîcriticism, setbacks, & the occasional existential crisis over why you ever signed up for this in the first place.

The best leaders don‚Äôt just survive these moments; they take them in stride. They don‚Äôt flinch, don‚Äôt spiral, & definitely don‚Äôt rage-post on LinkedIn about how ungrateful their team is. They absorb the blow, recalibrate, & move forward like it was all part of the plan.

An HBR study found that leaders who demonstrate emotional resilience in the face of criticism or failure foster 33% higher engagement among their teams. Meanwhile, those who react poorly create a ripple effect of stress, disengagement, & occasional popcorn-worthy workplace drama.

In other words, when you take setbacks in stride, your team learns to do the same. & that‚Äôs how you build a culture that can actually handle pressure‚Äîinstead of one that collectively loses its mind every time there‚Äôs a bad quarter.

Not sure if you take things in stride? Here‚Äôs a quick test:

‚Ä¢ Someone gives you tough feedback. Do you: A) Thank them & reflect on it? (Good.) B) Spend the next 48 hours coming up with a strategic revenge plan? (Bad.)

‚Ä¢ A project flops. Do you: A) Gather your team, assess what went wrong, & move forward? (Good.) B) Launch into a dramatic monologue about how nobody respects your genius? (Bad.)

‚Ä¢ A team member challenges your decision. Do you: A) Listen & evaluate their perspective? (Good.) B) Reply with, "Do you know who I am?!" (Bad & also embarrassing.)

If you find yourself leaning toward the "bad" column, don‚Äôt worry. Here‚Äôs how you can develop this essential leadership skill:

1. Pause before you react ‚Äî When hit with criticism or bad news, don‚Äôt react immediately. Take a breath. Count to six. Or, if necessary, step outside & scream into the void (privately).

2. Reframe the setback ‚Äî Instead of seeing failures or critiques as personal attacks, view them as data. What can you learn? How can this make you better?

3. Keep the big picture in mind ‚Äî Will this matter in a month? A year? Most things that feel like earthquakes today are barely speed bumps in hindsight.

4. Lead by example ‚Äî If you panic, your team panics. If you stay cool, they stay cool. Simple as that.

Leadership will always throw curveballs your way. If you take every hit personally, you won‚Äôt last long. But if you take things in stride, you‚Äôll build resilience‚Äînot just for yourself, but for your entire team.

So, the next time someone drops a load of criticism on you, just smile, nod, & keep moving. & maybe, just maybe, invest in a metaphorical helmet.

comments.commentText: Indeed - it‚Äôs not about avoiding setbacks, but about handling them with grace and turning them into learning opportunities.

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Resilience in leadership is key to fostering a strong, united team. Its all about turning obstacles into growth opportunities! üå±

3/ Making yourself irreplaceable.
‚Ü≥ Document your role and train your replacement.

4/ Thinking work friends are real friends.
‚Ü≥ Schedule coffee with someone two levels up. Monthly.

5/ Waiting for permission to lead.
‚Ü≥ Find a broken process. Fix it without being asked.

6/ Playing the long-term game.
‚Ü≥ Build skills that travel, not roots that trap.

7/ Avoiding office politics.
‚Ü≥ Build three allies above your pay grade.

8/ Hiding behind hard work.
‚Ü≥ Turn wins into visible process improvements.

9/ Trusting HR is on your side.
‚Ü≥ Document everything. Build your own evidence trail.

10/ Saving questions for later.
‚Ü≥ Ask the awkward question in the big meeting.

11/ Chasing titles over skills.
‚Ü≥ Focus on building rare, valuable skills.

12/ Becoming too specialized.
‚Ü≥ Learn adjacent skills. Build breadth and depth.

13/ Avoiding difficult conversations.
‚Ü≥ Address issues early. Be direct but kind.

14/ Not building your network.
‚Ü≥ Build one new connection weekly. Stay in touch monthly.

15/ Ignoring industry trends.
‚Ü≥ Read industry news daily. Learn one new tool monthly.

16/ Taking credit instead of giving it.
‚Ü≥ Highlight their contributions. Build through generosity.

17/ Not negotiating early offers.
‚Ü≥ Research market rates. Ask for more than is comfortable.

18/ Staying too long in one role.
‚Ü≥ Change roles every 2-3 years. Seek new challenges.

19/ Not building personal brand.
‚Ü≥ Share insights weekly. Build thought leadership.

20/ Avoiding all risk.
‚Ü≥ Take one calculated risk quarterly.

21/ Working without metrics.
‚Ü≥ Define key success metrics. Track and share results.

---

P.S. - Don't forget to check the carousel for how to spot each mistake.

postsData.content:
When my husband scores a good parking spot, either in the first row or right by the door‚Ä¶‚Ä¶

He says, ‚ÄúNobody puts Baby in the corner.‚Äù

That‚Äôs me. I‚Äôm Baby. Lol. 

He‚Äôs been saying this for all of the 30 years we‚Äôve been married.

The flying dance move, also made famous by the classic movie Dirty Dancin‚Ä¶. has been copied by tons of other movies.

It‚Äôs been performed at hundreds, if not thousands of weddings, parties and events.

You may have even attempted that move in the privacy of your own home with a trusted partner. (We listen and we don‚Äôt judge).

When Dirty Dancing came out, waaaaaay back in 1987, it was WIDELY panned by critics.

In fact, the most famous movie reviewers of the time, Rodger and Ebert gave it a paltry 1 star ‚≠êÔ∏è.

But that didn‚Äôt stop people from loving it. It made over $170MM dollars within months of it‚Äôs release.

Just because something doesn‚Äôt always get the respect it deserves, doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs not worth it.

Whether it‚Äôs a movie, your job or something else that doesn‚Äôt seem like it‚Äôs a good fit, there‚Äôs always someone else who will think it (or you) are amazing.

Sometimes, you just have to find the right audience.

comments.commentText: Amen! Plus my wife always takes credit for good parking spots due to "mojo" and criticizes me for parking too far out and not trusting the magic!!

Time and time again I still hear that AI or automating isn't something that is going to stick...Do you all really feel that this is a fad and will go away? I don't think so and encourage others to embrace and implement to not fall behind.

Implementing the right tools can streamline operations and enhance decision-making:

Automation Tools: Use software to handle routine tasks such as invoicing, payroll, and reconciliations. If you can take manual tasks away from team members you free them up to focus on other critical tasks and you also help eliminate errors.

Data Analysis: Leverage financial insights to drive better decision-making and strategy. Do you primarily use Excel or something like PowerBI?

Cloud-Based Solutions: Improve collaboration and access to real-time data for greater flexibility. I use Google for my business and clients. That‚Äôs been very easy to manage and allows them direct access to everything we are doing.



Being able to help in this area has been a blast the past two years. If you have questions or issues in this area, join our free newsletter or online community to learn more.

postsData.content:
How to Destroy a Deal in 45 Minutes (A Masterclass) 

Picture this: You get a pitch. 

It‚Äôs 12 pages long. It‚Äôs in Word (yes, Word).

It‚Äôs packed with more jargon than a legal thriller, and oh, there are seven different options to choose from.

Seven.

Like I‚Äôm at a buffet deciding between mashed potatoes or quinoa.

By the end of the pitch, I had:

‚Ä¢ A headache.
‚Ä¢ Zero understanding of what problem they could solve.
‚Ä¢ And a deep, primal urge to set my inbox on fire.

Here‚Äôs what went wrong:

 They gave me everything but clarity.

 Instead of confidence, I felt like I needed a translator and a therapist.

 No one addressed the big question: What‚Äôs in it for me?

At the 45-minute mark, I tapped out.

I wasn‚Äôt interested. I wasn‚Äôt engaged. I was mentally googling ‚ÄúHow to fake bad WiFi.‚Äù

Let‚Äôs get real:

No one cares about your company‚Äôs long history or how many words you can cram into a document.

Not until you can answer one simple question:

 Can you solve my problem?

If you‚Äôre pitching, here‚Äôs how not to suck at it:

Ô∏è Be clear. Like, ‚Äúcrystal-clear vodka‚Äù clear.

Ô∏è Tell me what‚Äôs in it for me. No jargon. No fluff.

Ô∏è Stop offering seven options. I barely trust myself to pick a sandwich.


The best pitch I ever got?

Two pages. One solution.

I walked away thinking, ‚ÄúWow, they get it.‚Äù

So, please: don‚Äôt be the 12-page Word document of pitches.

Be the two-pager that wins.

What‚Äôs the worst pitch you‚Äôve ever received?

How long does it take? 

To get your freelance business up and running so it brings in good clients on a reliable basis and turns a healthy profit?

Six months.

Six figures is down the line a bit. (Honestly, I'm not a fan of that metric. There are better ways to measure success.)

But there‚Äôs a catch.

That six months can be shortened to three months or can drag on for years.

Because it‚Äôs not a measure of time. It‚Äôs a measure of what you achieve.

There are very specific milestones every freelance business must reach.

Six months is just a reasonable timeframe for doing that.

If your aim for 2024 is to establish the foundations of a thriving freelance business, then you need to get those milestones behind you as quickly as possible.

How?

By switching from windfall clients to system clients.

By understanding how leveraging 10% efficiency improvements translates into 100% profit bumps.

And by seizing on the enormous revenue potential of not being that good at the business stuff right now (seriously, that one shift will put more money in your pocket than anything else I can think of until you crack six figures).

postsData.content:
BIOMIMICRY CONTINUUM ‚Äì Part 4 ‚Äì Update Agent LEARNING
Fundamental evidence of learning is the ability to recall and utilize what is learned. Receiving and integrating new information is a starting point. It is not learning, but an exceedingly small subset.
Recent research published in Nature uncovered that Concept Cells help our brain abstract information and build memories. (,)

A report in Quanta magazine () provides an example: The idea of a ‚Äúbank‚Äù has its own set of concept cells, maybe millions of them. Concept neurons fire for their concept no matter how it is presented: in real life or a photo, in text or speech, on television or in a podcast. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs more abstract, really different from what you‚Äôre seeing,‚Äù said Elizabeth Buffalo, a neuroscientist at the University of Washington.

These discoveries support and align with the abstraction methodology discussed in Part 2 and the contextualization methodology in Part 3.



In contrast to how the brain learns, LLMs:
-process all ingested data rather than filtering for relevance, and
-output the detailed words and pixels based on statistical proximity rather than conceptual value
The aim is to pass the Turing test, output that imitates the appearance of intelligence sufficiently to deceive the user.

The correctness of the result is dependent on the concentrations of relevant data in the training content. AI speed hides the fact that the model does not ‚Äúknow‚Äù anything but rather recomputes even identical prompts.

On the other hand, by imitating the learning and memory architecture and methodology of the brain the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem creates a library of reusable expertise and continues to learn. Imagine the applications when expertise is in high demand but sparse due to "brain drain" scenarios, new science and technology, or economic constraints.

In part 5 I will discuss the curation methodology.
postsData.commentAdded: Fascinating insights on learning! Bridging brain mimicry and AI opens doors to innovative solutions in expertise management. Excited for Part 5!

postsData.content:
How I got 1,200+ shares on ONE LinkedIn post 

My LinkedIn post went viral. 

And by viral up, I mean‚Ä¶
 10,000+ followers overnight
 10 million views
 4,000+ comments

After that, I spent hours studying why it took off. What actually made people engage, share, and comment?

Here‚Äôs what I learned (and how you can apply it too):

 Your hook is everything.
‚Üí If your first sentence doesn‚Äôt grab attention, nothing else matters.

Your hook should make people stop scrolling and feel curious enough to keep reading.

Pro tip: Study posts that go viral (especially from creators without huge followings) and analyse what made their opening line work.

________________

 Format matters more than you think.
‚Üí No one wants to read a huge block of text. Make it skimmable.

Use spacing, emojis, and bullet points to break up ideas and keep people engaged.

________________

 Know exactly why you‚Äôre posting.
‚Üí Before you hit publish, ask yourself: What‚Äôs the goal of this post?

Are you trying to educate, entertain, inspire, or start a conversation? The clearer your message, the better the engagement.

________________

 Use the algorithm to your advantage.
‚Üí Whether we like it or not, the algorithm matters.

If LinkedIn is pushing selfies, post selfies. If engaging with comments early boosts reach, reply quickly. If a certain type of content is performing well, lean into it.

________________

The truth is, virality can be random‚Äîbut there are patterns.

Once you recognise them, you can apply them to every post you create.

Which of these do you think makes the biggest difference? Let me know in the comments

postsData.content:
Want to stop clients from scope creeping?

Learn to ask this simple question:

Why?

I chat with agency owners weekly who speak about scope creep like it‚Äôs a disease they‚Äôve been afflicted with.

I‚Äôm throwing a snowball at your head.

If a client scope creeps, and you let them, are we still seeing this as an unsolvable problem?

Here‚Äôs the antidote.

No fear. No combativeness. No awkward turtle.

Ask.
Them.
Why.

Example: I‚Äôve served hundreds of manufacturing clients in my SEO career.

I‚Äôd always hear this: ‚ÄúWe need to be on social media.‚Äù

This is what you hear: ‚ÄúThey can pay me more.‚Äù

But you‚Äôll find a way to underprice it
they‚Äôll ask for more than you agreed
and the vicious cycle continues.

My approach?

‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù

It‚Äôs not your job to say yes.
It‚Äôs your job to serve them to the best of your ability.

My clients would often say, ‚ÄúWe think it‚Äôs what we need to do.‚Äù

Again, ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù

Over and over and over I‚Äôd ask until we realized they thought it was a good idea but didn‚Äôt have a real reason.

Here‚Äôs how I‚Äôd serve them to the best of my ability:

‚ÄúIf we‚Äôve established that it‚Äôs highly unlikely you‚Äôll get more immediate business from social media, but you‚Äôre already seeing traction from our SEO work, can I propose that, if there‚Äôs more in the budget, we double down on what‚Äôs working instead of lose focus on something we don‚Äôt have a guarantee for?‚Äù

This is how you say no to a client.

They scope creep because you‚Äôre saying yes instead of serving them to the
best of your ability.

Cool? Cool.

Hate saying no to clients and need systems for how to do it effectively‚Äîwithout fearing churn?

comments.commentText: Love this, Colby. Asking ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù shifts the focus from just agreeing to actually understanding the core need - and often, clients realize they don‚Äôt need more, they just need what‚Äôs already working to be amplified.
What a great way to approach clients who think they can 'outsmart' the expert they just hired, or just want to do more, blindly betting on things that they 'feel' might work

postsData.commentAdded: Great advice! Asking Why? not only clarifies needs but also empowers us to guide clients toward the best solutions. üí°#ClientSuccess #AgencyGrowth

10 Powerful Lessons Life Has Taught Me


Life has been my greatest teacher, and along the way, I‚Äôve learned lessons that have shaped me into who I am today.


Some came through wins, others through struggles, but all have been valuable.

Here are 10 things life has taught me:

'n Your mindset determines your reality. If you believe you can, you‚Äôre halfway there.

'n Nobody owes you anything. Take responsibility for your growth, your success, and your happiness.

'n Consistency beats talent. It‚Äôs not about how skilled you are; it‚Äôs about how often you show up.

'n Rejection is redirection. Every "no" is just pushing you closer to the right opportunity.

'n Your network is your net worth. Surround yourself with people who inspire and challenge you.

'n Done is better than perfect. Perfectionism kills progress. Start now and improve as you go.

'n Money flows where value goes. Focus on providing solutions, and opportunities will come.

'n Rest is productive. Burnout isn‚Äôt a badge of honor‚Äîlisten to your body and recharge.

'n Learn to say no. Protecting your time and energy is self-respect.

'n You are your best investment. Never stop learning, growing, and betting on yourself.
